language why that i think you know i think it matters in the world of embedded development working with
microcontrollers single board computers all that fun hardware stuff i'll start with a bit of history
talk about some of the flavors of python available on devices and then i'll mix in a few demos
along the way but first let me start by stating why i think python matters whether you are an
embedded developer used to c or c plus or a software engineer potentially interested in working in this space
which is where i came from and i think that's probably where most of us are as well
and it starts with complexity frankly a lot of the software in the hardware and hardware world revolves around how we
can actually deliver products how we actually get things into production how we get things
across the finish line and you know this well as a developer if you're working on a site or an app there are a number of
things that can trip you up or slow you down and this is absolutely true in the hardware world as well where the
existence of atoms adds even more complexity beyond the bits and bytes that we already have to deal with as
software developers and when i think about complexity i think about a quote from ray ozzy the
ceo and founder of my company blues wireless and that quote is complexity kills and
i'm guessing that many of you have heard that one before or heard something like it because it's something that ray said
many years ago in his software days before starting blues wireless and in the embedded world part of the
complexity lies in languages and tool chains where there hasn't really been as much
innovation as there has been in the desktop computing world and i could start take this moment and start
criticizing the and c plus plus languages or making some sort of joke at their expense so i'm not going to do
that but i will say that c and c plus plus aren't for everyone and the learning curve for these languages is
quite steep in fact i'm guessing that there are some of you in the room that have that experienced c or c plus plus
at some point in your career and decided that you don't ever want to go there again that's a common refrain that i
hear a lot of times but when it comes to considering programming languages and embedded
systems we should consider the bit that businesses around the world are set to deploy billions more embedded
and connected devices in the coming years and these devices need developers many many more developers than those
that are working professionally with c and c plus plus today a lot of the explosion that we've seen of opportunity
around software development because of desktop and cloud computing and mobile is still there and even broader and
larger for the world of iot where there are billions upon billions and some project even trillions of devices in our
future so the question then becomes what are our options as an industry if we want to
enable the next 50 billion embedded devices do we insist that c and c plus
are the only path through the door or do we consider another approach now if you are a c or c plus plus
aficionado you might tell me that according to the tob index for august of 2021 c is still the most popular
language with c plus plus at number four and you'd be right although it is
important to note that python did move solidly into the number two slot over the last year there's no doubt that c is
still a very popular language in terms of what people are using for the apps that they're building today
but what if we looked at the data a different way what if instead we looked at not what
people are actively using not what we're all using professionally today but what people are learning and hope to use in
the future because i believe that's the best indicator of where the long-term opportunity lies and here the data are
pretty clear based on an analysis of people searching for language tutorials python is the
clear favorite right the point of this chart is to say that people that are looking people that want to learn
something new are by and large choosing python is the language that they want to learn and there's a lot of reasons for this
python is already a language that canon is being used in a ton of different areas from web development to machine
learning data visualization game development and more and it's also becoming the most popular language for
introducing coding to students whether they're kids or adults if you're new to programming by and large people
are choosing python as the entry place the entry point to go in so if we in the iot and the embedded
world are looking to pin down the next generation of what devices will be built in and how they will be built and what
they will run i think we can look no further than python now before i get into the specifics of
what that means on individual devices i thought it might be helpful to share a few of the advantages of python on
devices as i see it if you're already a fan of python these might not be news to you but if it's a language that you know
about you've dabbled in you're sort of generally interested in or not maybe these things will be interesting
the first and this is probably my favorite is that there's no compilation in python python is an interpreted
language whether you're working with it on a desktop or whether you're working with it in a microcontroller
you don't have to worry about setting up crazy compiler tool chains in order to use the language and for somebody that
spends a lot of their time day in and day out working with embedded devices the saving of the compilation step is
actually pretty nice those of you that work in the web and work in desktop computing
environments and things like that are lucky because you don't have the same experience of waiting sometimes a
long time for a binary to compile before it goes on an embedded device the second thing and this is probably my
favorite is a live repel live debugging so if you've ever worked with python before you're familiar with this you've
experienced the use of the rebel and i'm actually excited to share that this is something that is available on
microcontrollers on embedded devices as well and we'll look at that and look at that in a little bit but this ability to
actually jump into a running device or a running program and inspect how it's going expect what it's what it's doing
without having to get into the complexity of step based debugging is really nice
the third advantage is machine learning on single board computers and on microcontrollers
we did a workshop on machine learning in the iot in the cloud the last couple of days and this is something that's near
and dear to me i'm a big fan of machine learning in general it's an area i've spent a lot of time in the last several years but it's also an area that i think
there's a lot of power between ai and ml and the iot right and so having the
ability to actually perform inferencing to actually capture sensor data and evaluate that in real time and python is
another area where there's a lot of work and a lot of interest happening and then finally it's it's just python um i say

now over the next little bit i do want to spend a moment talking about the internet of things because this is an
important piece here it's great to be able to use python on these devices it's great to be able to
program microcontroller microcontrollers in this way but the reason why we're interested in this as an industry and as
developers is because we need to take that data and send it somewhere we need remote monitoring we need remote control
i recognize that not every embedded application is or not every not every embedded application is a connected
application but more and more of the devices that we're building rely on some kind of connectivity even if it's
something even if it's something very close by like bluetooth or nfc some sort of connectivity between devices whether
we're talking about those two or wi-fi or laura or cellular so
there's good news for the python world here because there's an increasing number of iot vendors out there who are
building for python developers not just insisting that you have to work with classic embedded languages in order to
work with a space one such example is my company blues wireless and we tend to focus on providing device agnostic ways
of connecting sensors and applications because we recognize that the reality is that most developers out there most
companies out there are looking to get their sensors their information into their ultimate cloud applications
whether it's their own infrastructure or something like aws azure gcp etc right
and all of this middle piece here is a mess when i mentioned that idea of complexity earlier all of this stuff
tends to be really difficult and time consuming for developers and i think it has created this world where we tend not
to start the projects that we really want to be able to build and our product set starts with something called the note card which is
a low power cellular and gps device that has 100 that has cellular iot connectivity in over 135 countries
including pretty much all of europe and portugal the device comes with 10 years and 500
megs of data baked into the cost of the device so there's no monthly data plans no activation fees the price is on the
tin basically so i come from a world where in the cellular iot space for years we have
been used to this idea of well i got to buy a device and i have to buy a sim card and i have to pay a five bucks a
month for a sim card a lot of the mobile operators out there priced their cellular iot devices like mini mobile
data plans where you got to sign up for something and for me as a developer that stopped me from starting and piloting

connection to our cloud services baked into the device so there's no error prone uh security problems no error from
key rotation or cloud provisioning you literally just power it up start sending it data and it knows where to go in
